questions.text: Which of the following Motor neuron disease involves only upper motor neuron
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary lateral sclerosis Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) is a motor neuron disease that primarily involves only the upper motor neurons. It is characterized by progressive spasticity, hyperreflexia, and weakness due to the degeneration of upper motor neurons, which are located in the brain and spinal cord. PLS does not involve the lower motor neurons, meaning it does not cause the muscle wasting and atrophy typically seen in conditions affecting both upper and lower motor neurons. While PLS can resemble amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in its presentation, it remains restricted to upper motor neuron dysfunction. Incorrect Answers: A. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): ALS affects both upper and lower motor neurons, leading to both muscle weakness (from lower motor neuron involvement) and spasticity (from upper motor neuron involvement). Therefore, ALS involves both motor neuron types, making it incorrect as a disease that involves only the upper motor neurons. C. Adult Tay-Sachs disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of gangliosides in the nervous system. While the disease can cause neurological symptoms, including motor impairments, it is not classified as a motor neuron disease, and it affects both the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system, rather than solely upper motor neurons. D. Kennedy’s disease: Kennedy’s disease, also known as spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy, is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor gene. This disease involves both upper and lower motor neurons and leads to progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations. Therefore, it is not limited to the upper motor neurons.

questions.text: Amyotropic lateral sclerosis can be diagnosed by all of the following except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bladder involvement Bladder involvement is not typically seen in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and is not used as a diagnostic feature. While ALS primarily affects the motor neurons responsible for voluntary muscle control, it does not generally involve the autonomic nervous system, which controls bladder function. Therefore, bladder dysfunction is not a hallmark of ALS and is unlikely to be part of the diagnostic criteria for the disease. If bladder issues are present, they are more likely related to other conditions, not ALS. Incorrect Answers: A. Wasting of muscle: Muscle wasting (atrophy) is one of the primary signs of ALS. As the disease progresses, both upper and lower motor neurons are affected, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. This is a key diagnostic feature of ALS. B. Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes: Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, or hyperreflexia, can be observed in ALS due to the involvement of the upper motor neurons. Upper motor neuron damage leads to a loss of inhibition, causing the reflexes to become exaggerated. This is a common finding in ALS. C. Absent deep tendon reflexes: Absent deep tendon reflexes, or hyporeflexia, can be seen in ALS, especially as the disease progresses and affects the lower motor neurons. Lower motor neuron damage causes a loss of reflexes, which is another diagnostic feature of ALS.

questions.text: All of the following are never involved structures in MND except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nuclei of cranial nerves In motor neuron diseases (MND), the nuclei of cranial nerves can be involved, particularly in the later stages of the disease. The involvement of cranial nerve nuclei is seen in conditions like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), where the motor neurons that control the muscles of the face, throat, and tongue are affected. This leads to symptoms such as dysarthria (difficulty speaking), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and facial weakness. Therefore, cranial nerve nuclei can indeed be affected in MND, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Answers: A. Bladder: The bladder is typically not involved in MND. While the disease affects the motor neurons controlling voluntary muscle function, the autonomic nervous system, which regulates bladder function, is generally spared in MND. Bladder dysfunction is not a common or characteristic feature of these disorders. C. Ocular muscles: Ocular muscles are usually spared in MND. Although ALS can cause eye muscle weakness in some cases, the ocular muscles are not typically involved early in the disease. Unlike other neurological conditions that affect eye movements, MND does not primarily impact the muscles controlling eye movement. D. Cognition: Cognitive changes can occur in some individuals with MND, particularly in ALS, but they are not typically a core feature of the disease. In some cases, patients may develop frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which is a separate but related condition. However, cognition is generally not a primary area of involvement in the majority of MND cases.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the site of lesion in motor neuron disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior horn cells In motor neuron diseases (MND), the primary site of lesion is the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. These cells are the lower motor neurons responsible for transmitting signals from the central nervous system to the muscles, thereby facilitating voluntary movement. In MND, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), these anterior horn cells degenerate and die, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations. The damage to these motor neurons is central to the pathophysiology of MND. Incorrect Answers: B. Peripheral nerve: The peripheral nerves are not the primary site of damage in MND. While peripheral nerves are affected secondarily as they are the pathways through which the lower motor neurons send signals to muscles, the underlying cause of MND lies in the degeneration of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, particularly the anterior horn cells. C. Spinothalamic tract: The spinothalamic tract is involved in transmitting sensory information, including pain and temperature, from the body to the brain. It is not involved in motor control, and therefore, is not the site of lesion in motor neuron diseases, which affect motor neurons rather than sensory pathways. D. Spinocerebellar tract: The spinocerebellar tract is responsible for transmitting proprioceptive information (sensory input regarding the position of limbs) to the cerebellum for coordination of movement. Like the spinothalamic tract, it is a sensory pathway and does not typically involve motor neurons, thus it is not the site of lesion in MND.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Death of posterior horn cell neurons In amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), the primary pathological process involves the degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons, specifically the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and the motor neurons in the motor cortex of the brain. The posterior horn cells, which are part of the spinal cord's sensory pathways, are not typically affected in ALS. Therefore, the death of posterior horn cell neurons is not a characteristic feature of ALS, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Answers: A. More common in male than female: ALS is indeed more common in males than in females. The incidence and prevalence of ALS are higher in men, particularly in the earlier stages of the disease. This gender difference in incidence is well-documented in clinical studies of ALS. C. Death of neurons in motor cortex in cerebral hemisphere: One of the key features of ALS is the death of motor neurons, including those located in the motor cortex of the cerebral hemisphere. This degeneration is responsible for the progressive muscle weakness and atrophy that are characteristic of ALS. The loss of motor neurons in both the upper motor neurons (in the brain) and lower motor neurons (in the spinal cord) is central to the pathophysiology of ALS. D. Bladder is not involved: Bladder dysfunction is generally not a prominent feature of ALS, as the disease primarily affects voluntary motor control. ALS involves the motor neurons that control voluntary muscles, but it does not typically cause autonomic dysfunction, such as bladder issues. While autonomic disturbances can occur in some advanced cases, bladder involvement is not a common symptom in ALS.

choices.text: A long history of remissions and exacerbations
Sensory loss in the distribution of peripheral nerves

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of clumsiness with both hands, like having difficulty doing up buttons or using his keys. Physical examination reveals fasciculations of his thigh and forearm muscles; diffuse muscle weakness, loss of muscle bulk, and increased tone in the upper and lower limbs. There is generalized hyperreflexia, and positive Babinski signs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely natural progression of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A progressively downhill course. This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. ALS is a neurodegenerative disease that affects both the upper motor neurons (in the brain) and lower motor neurons (in the spinal cord). The fasciculations, muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, hyperreflexia, and positive Babinski signs are classic features of this condition, indicating both upper motor neuron (spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski) and lower motor neuron involvement (fasciculations, muscle atrophy, weakness). ALS follows a progressively downhill course, with worsening symptoms over time, leading to severe disability and eventual respiratory failure due to involvement of respiratory muscles. Why other options are incorrect: A. A long history of remissions and exacerbations: ALS is a progressive disease without periods of remission or exacerbation. It has a steady decline, and the symptoms worsen over time without any recovery. In contrast, diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS) may have remissions and exacerbations. Therefore, a history of remissions and exacerbations is inconsistent with ALS. B. Sensory loss in the distribution of peripheral nerves: ALS primarily affects motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. It does not typically cause sensory loss since sensory neurons are generally spared in ALS. Sensory involvement would suggest a different condition, such as peripheral neuropathy or multifocal motor neuropathy, but it is not characteristic of ALS. C. Focal seizures: Focal seizures are not a typical manifestation of ALS. ALS is a motor neuron disease, and while it can affect the motor function of muscles, it does not usually cause seizures. Seizures are more commonly associated with conditions like epilepsy, stroke, or brain tumors, rather than ALS. The progressive motor symptoms seen in ALS do not lead to seizure activity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with weakness and fasciculations in his arms and legs. His cranial nerves are normal, but there is weakness of his left handgrip and right leg quadriceps with loss of muscle bulk. There are obvious fasciculations over the left forearm and right thigh. Tone is increased in the arms and legs and the reflexes are brisk. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects both the upper motor neurons (located in the brain) and lower motor neurons (located in the spinal cord and brainstem). Key features of ALS include muscle weakness, fasciculations (involuntary muscle twitches), muscle atrophy, and hyperreflexia (increased reflexes). This patient's weakness, particularly in the left handgrip and right leg quadriceps, along with muscle bulk loss and fasciculations in the forearm and thigh, are classic signs of motor neuron degeneration. The increased muscle tone (spasticity) and brisk reflexes also point toward upper motor neuron involvement, which is characteristic of ALS. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Myotonic muscular dystrophy: Myotonic muscular dystrophy is a genetic muscle disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and the inability to relax muscles after contraction (myotonia). While weakness and muscle wasting can occur in myotonic dystrophy, it typically affects the distal muscles first, such as those of the hands and lower legs, and often presents with myotonia (difficulty releasing grip or relaxing after muscle contraction). The patient's symptoms of fasciculations, increased tone, and brisk reflexes point more to motor neuron disease than to muscular dystrophy, and there is no mention of myotonia in this case. C. Tabes dorsalis: Tabes dorsalis is a late manifestation of syphilis, characterized by degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, which primarily affects proprioception and vibration sense. Symptoms include impaired gait, loss of coordination (ataxia), and lightning-like pains in the limbs, but it does not typically cause fasciculations or muscle atrophy. The presence of muscle weakness, fasciculations, and hyperreflexia in this patient is not consistent with tabes dorsalis, making this diagnosis unlikely. D. Migraine: Migraine is a primary headache disorder that can present with visual disturbances, nausea, and photophobia, but it does not typically cause muscle weakness, fasciculations, or muscle atrophy. The neurological signs described in this patient—muscle weakness, fasciculations, muscle atrophy, increased tone, and brisk reflexes—are far more suggestive of a motor neuron disease like ALS than a migraine. Therefore, migraine is not a likely diagnosis.
